question.title: method ID not in [0, 0xffff]: 65536 error in a small app

node.contents: `We only have 500+ unused methods` ... **only**! Try grouping your methods, in order to have less. And please remove all unused ones.

astNode.text: `We only have 500+ unused methods` ... **only**! Try grouping your methods, in order to have less. And please remove all unused ones.

node.contents: Hello Frank, the 500+ unused methods where from the libs that we have included in our project. Ours was very small with only around 100 very short classes.

astNode.text: Hello Frank, the 500+ unused methods where from the libs that we have included in our project. Ours was very small with only around 100 very short classes.

node.contents: Edit the libs...

astNode.text: Edit the libs...

node.contents: Yeah, we use them all. we do have the ormlite for the db. jackson for the json. okhttp, okio, picasso and retrofit for the network. google play services for location, email login, place, etc. google maps for business for the map. butterknife for injecting views and braintree for payments.

astNode.text: Yeah, we use them all. we do have the ormlite for the db. jackson for the json. okhttp, okio, picasso and retrofit for the network. google play services for location, email login, place, etc. google maps for business for the map. butterknife for injecting views and braintree for payments.

node.contents: You has to many libs. Are you sure you should use them all ?

astNode.text: You has to many libs. Are you sure you should use them all ?

node.contents: We do have a small app, though, using around 10jars. I am stuck with it. I configured Proguard and it still says the same thing. We only have 500+ unused methods as per the Proguard results. What could I be doing wrong or missing?

node.contents: Thanks in Advance.

astNode.text: Thanks in Advance.

node.contents: I just realized that Proguard turned on, without additional configurations work in a project that does not have any module dependency. I am trying to let it work in a module which is a dependency of the main project I am running. I tried to put Proguard on both and it is not removing the needed stuff. Thanks

astNode.text: I just realized that Proguard turned on, without additional configurations work in a project that does not have any module dependency. I am trying to let it work in a module which is a dependency of the main project I am running. I tried to put Proguard on both and it is not removing the needed stuff. Thanks

node.contents: Hi @EricLafortune, the Proguard worked now, but was only able to strip 400+ methods from Google play Services. Is that expected? Thanks

astNode.text: Hi @EricLafortune, the Proguard worked now, but was only able to strip 400+ methods from Google play Services. Is that expected? Thanks

node.contents: ProGuard can probably remove many classes and methods for you, but your configuration is fairly conservative, explicitly keeping many classes, fields, and methods:

astNode.text: ProGuard can probably remove many classes and methods for you, but your configuration is fairly conservative, explicitly keeping many classes, fields, and methods:

node.contents: You may have even more options in a separate file, e.g. for the Facebook SDK?

astNode.text: You may have even more options in a separate file, e.g. for the Facebook SDK?

node.contents: Note that the file proguard-project.txt can essentially be empty to start with, since the bulk of the configuration is already specified in the shared configuration file ${sdk.dir}/tools/proguard/proguard-android.txt (referenced from project.properties). Creating a better configuration with the right -keep options may then require some research and experimentation.

astNode.text: Note that the file proguard-project.txt can essentially be empty to start with, since the bulk of the configuration is already specified in the shared configuration file ${sdk.dir}/tools/proguard/proguard-android.txt (referenced from project.properties). Creating a better configuration with the right -keep options may then require some research and experimentation.

node.contents: You also shouldn't specify -injars or -libraryjars options in your configuration file. The Gradle build process already automatically specifies all the necessary -injars, -outjars, and -libraryjars for you.

astNode.text: You also shouldn't specify -injars or -libraryjars options in your configuration file. The Gradle build process already automatically specifies all the necessary -injars, -outjars, and -libraryjars for you.

node.contents: So, I was able to fix it. The proguard code was actually fine, but I placed it in the wrong file. It should be in the module which generates the dex file. I have placed it in the static library before.

astNode.text: So, I was able to fix it. The proguard code was actually fine, but I placed it in the wrong file. It should be in the module which generates the dex file. I have placed it in the static library before.

node.contents: Also, I used https://gist.github.com/dmarcato/d7c91b94214acd936e42 to strip out the Google Play Services packages that I do not use. I placed the code in the gradle file of the module which generates the APK.

astNode.text: Also, I used https://gist.github.com/dmarcato/d7c91b94214acd936e42 to strip out the Google Play Services packages that I do not use. I placed the code in the gradle file of the module which generates the APK.

node.contents: Thanks. :)

astNode.text: Thanks. :)
